Chris, shifting health care costs from government to individuals would increase overall costs because individuals do not have the market power necessary to achieve significant reductions in cost.

The simple fact is that most health care expenses are incurred during significant crises, such as heart attacks or cancer, or at the end of life. In both of those areas, individuals are unable to shop around for the best price. Conversely, the areas where individuals can shop around tends to be on things like preventive care, which we actually want to encourage more of, not less. Finally, having individuals operating in the private insurance market means more money devoted to administrative costs, advertising, and profit margins.

By contrast, government insurance programs are able to help hold down costs, because they have lower administrative costs and they aren't seeking a profit. In addition, government is able to negotiate for lower prices and to implement comparative effectiveness programs that help ensure that health care dollars are going towards treatments that are effective, rather than just ones that are well-advertised.

The above reasons are why Medicare has held costs down better than private insurance. The key moving forward is expanding Medicare, and enhancing its ability to rationalize health care spending, rather than rationing care.

"Incrementalism" ?!  You mean, "Freedom for white Americans now, Mr. Adams. We'll worry about the black ones later."  Sorry, Mr. Douthat, but health care shouldn't be looked upon as some sort of commodity to be traded on the market by wealthy investors who don't have to worry about its costs. It's absoIutely mind-boggling that the U.S. is the only nation in the industrialized world not to have universal health coverage.  The only nation in which infants and adolescents don't receive treatment for illness and injury because their parents can't afford to pay the bills.  The only nation in which senior citizens have to choose between medicine and food when they can't afford to purchase both.  Justice Kennedy (the Court's so-called "swing man") had the effrontery to speak of the "rights" of insurance companies this week even as he neglected the rights of patients to have their medical coverage transferred from one place of employment to another and to be protected from price gouging if they suddenly became seriously ill.  Instead of worrying about whether this nation will somehow lose its soul in the tentacles of European" Socialism" (boo! hiss!) we should instead rediscover our own souls by seeing to it that affordable health care becomes available to all.  No equivocations and no excuses!
